author: dcposch
content:
To expand on what <@301186049323958275> said, client diversity becomes more important post-merge because PoS has stronger finality than PoW.

Strong finality is a plus, but it does make accidental forks (say, due to client bugs) more dangerous.

For a historical example, I recommend reading about Bitcoin's 2013 hard fork. They had (and still have) no client diversity at all; the entire network ran bitcoind, which had a bug.  The recovery ultimately reorg'd about 4 hours worth of chain history.

We won't necessarily have that privilege going forward. A finalized chain effectively cannot be reorged (good!). So we avoid getting into that situation in the first place by ensuring that no client implementation has too much stake.

content: It's worse for validators - if they wind up attesting to the invalid chain after it justified they can't return to the correct chain without creating a surround vote which is slashable.  Ultimately a very large amount of the staked ETH is going to be either slashed or leaked through inactivity penalities to get the chain back to finalizing.

author: thiago_crowdtainer

author: ajsutton
content:
From a user point of view I'm not sure it's really any different.  If your node follows the invalid chain you may make decisions based on bad data.  And then when you switch back to the correct chain, you'll wind up with a multi-hundred, possibly multi-thousand block re-org.

Of course, the same is true in PoW - if your node follows an invalid chain you're going to have to re-org back to the correct chain.  The only real difference is that with PoW you might automatically re-org back if the correct chain winds up with higher difficulty whereas in PoS you'll have to manually intervene to get back onto the correct chain.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think the TL;DR is that if you are running a validator, it is *strongly* in your best interest to not run a majority client pair, because it could result in you losing a large amount (possibly all) of your stake if there is a bug in your majority client that gets finalized.

author: sky.cactus
content: If you are a user, and you see/believe that some client is a majority client in the validator set, you want to make sure you *don't* run that client so that you can be more confident in finality not getting rolled back.

author: thiago_crowdtainer
content: OTOH, if I run a minority client, and that happens to have a bug (understandable since it‚Äôs not as mature as geth) , I‚Äôd also be ‚Äúslashed‚Äù (but to a lower degree), correct?

author: sky.cactus
content: If there is no majority client validator, then users can be more confident in finality regardless of their client pair, because the validators won't reach finality due to a bug in one client.

author: sky.cactus
content: You won't be able to reach finality, so you will just inactivity leak for a while I believe (someone else may be able to answer more confidently).

author: sky.cactus
content: IIUC, the penalties for a minority client with a bug forking off are *far* lower than a majority client forking off because the minority client will not finalize an invalid chain anytime soon (takes about 20 days before it starts to finalize the fork chain I think).
